#Text=4.
#Text=Evaluation Setup
#Text=In this section , we describe the benchmark dataset of the practical industrial process and the existing deep neural network approach that we used to compare our proposed method .
#Text=4.1. Tennessee Eastman Challenge Problem
#Text=We evaluate the performance of the proposed method for FDD on Tennessee Eastman Process ( TEP ) .
#Text=TEP is a widely-used benchmark testbed to investigate the large-scale control and FDD schemes of realistic chemical processes .
#Text=The simulation data of TEP are highly nonlinear with strong coupling and dynamical behavior .
#Text=The simulation code and data are available for download in References , respectively .
#Text=The main structure of the TEP simulator is described in
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=.
#Text=The TEP produces two products G and H from four reactants with additional byproduct F .
#Text=The reactions are
#Text=All chemical reactions are irreversible , exothermic and approximately first-order with respect to the reactant concentrations .
#Text=The reaction rates are a function of temperature through an Arrhenius expression .
#Text=The reaction to produce G has a higher activation energy than the one producing H , thus resulting in more sensitivity to temperature .
#Text=To model a practical industrial process , the TEP simulator consists of five major units : reactor , condenser , compressor , separator and stripper .
#Text=The gaseous reactants are fed into the reactor where liquid products are formed .
#Text=The product stream of the reactor is cooled through a condenser and fed to a vapor-liquid separator .
#Text=Non-condensed components are recycled back to the reactor via a compressor .
#Text=Condensed components are moved to a product stripping column by stripping with feed stream number 4 to eliminate remaining reactants .
#Text=Products G and H are separated in a downstream refining section from the stripper base .
#Text=The inert and byproducts are purged as vapor from the vapor-liquid separator .
#Text=In TEP , we monitor a total of 52 variables including 41 measured variables and 11 manipulated variables .
#Text=The modern industrial systems interact with multiple subcomponents where each component has several different failure modes .
#Text=Furthermore , each failure mode typically has long-term dependencies along with short-term ones of time series data .
#Text=Besides normal data , Table 1 describes 20 different types of faults to evaluate various FDD methods .
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=shows the raw process variable deviations from their normal states when fault 02 is introduced at after the simulation started .
#Text=We also show the normalized variables by the mean and standard deviation of each feature .

#Text=Although the time-varying features of multivariate data are critical to identify the types of faults , the distinction between various types of faults is a challenging task due to the complex interaction among control processes .
#Text=In fact , the fault effect is considerably different for various process variables .
#Text=Furthermore , even if some variables are oscillating due to faults , there is a significant delay to recognize it as shown in
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=.
#Text=The combined autoencoder and LSTM network must mine the hidden features of time series data .
#Text=More detailed information of TEP is described in Reference .
#Text=The simulation starts to run in the normal state for .
#Text=The specific fault out of 20 different types is then injected and it continues to run for .
#Text=Hence , the total simulation time is based on the recommendation of the TEP model .
#Text=Each simulation of the fault repeats 500 times with various initial states and random noise .
#Text=We set the sampling time as ( 20 samples/h ) to support the fast fault detection and fault diagnosis .
#Text=We randomly select 80 % time series sample as training sets and the remaining sample as testing sets .
#Text=We only use the normal state samples without any faults to train the autoencoder for fault detection where anomalous and normal states correspond to positive and negative class , respectively .
#Text=In addition , 20 % of the whole training set is used as the validation set to optimize the decision threshold for the autoencoder .
#Text=On the other hand , the time series samples with temporal features are used to train the LSTM-based classifier .
#Text=In this training set , we remove the first of the normal state samples in each simulation .
#Text=Hence , each training set of the LSTM network consists with of normal data and of faulty state data .
#Text=The fraction of the normal state samples prior to faults is used to compensate the detection delay and the possible false positives of the autoencoder .
#Text=The input sequence of the testing set for LSTM includes time series data before the first event of the fault detection , captured by the autoencoder .
#Text=4.2. DCNN
#Text=In previous research , a deep convolutional neural network ( DCNN)-based approach achieves the best reported results in multivariate time series data from the simulated TEP dataset .
#Text=We compare the fault diagnosis performance of LSTM and DCNN-based approaches on the TEP dataset .
